newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania discount rate soars to 50 pct from 35 pct.
newsitem.headline: Romania discount rate soars to 50 pct from 35 pct.

text.p: Romania's National Bank (BNR) said on Monday it had jacked up its key indicative rate -- the discount rate -- to 50 percent from 35 percent.
The increase reflects a tighter monetary policy due to a surge in inflation and is in line with International Monetary Fund recommendations that the discount rate should be positive in real terms.
Year-on-year inflation quickened to 47.4 percent last November from October's 45.1 percent, sharply exceeding the 20 percent target agreed with the IMF for 1996.
Last year the IMF suspended a three-year standby credit of $460 million after criticising the lax policies of the leftist government thrown out in last November's general election.
The BNR's overdraft rate, similar to a Lombard rate, remained unchanged at 90 percent.
Domestic inter-bank money market prices and bank deposit rates are expected to rise in line with the discount rate.

The new centrist government has doubled fuel prices from January 1 in a bid to meet IMF recommendations that fuel prices be raised to world levels. The move is expected to trigger a rise in consummer prices in the coming weeks.
An IMF mission is expected in Bucharest this month to discuss a new loan accord with the reformist government headed by Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea.
